word along the highways of Burma there
is placed at regular distances away from
the dust of the road and under the cool
shade of a group of trees a small wooden
building called a rest house where the
weary traveler may rest awhile and allay
his thirst and assuage his hunger and
fatigue by partaking of the food and
water which the kindly inhabitants
placed there as a religious duty along
the great highway of life there are such
resting places away from the heat of
passion and the dust of disappointment
under the cool and refreshing shade of
lowly wisdom are the humble unimposing
rest houses of peace and the little
almost unnoticed by ways of blessedness
where alone the weary and footsore can
find strength and healing nor can these
byways be ignored without suffering
along the great road of life hurrying
and eager to reach some elusive goal
presses the multitude despising the
apparently insignificant rest houses of
true thought not heeding the narrow
little byways of blessed action which
they regard is unimportant an hour by
hour men are fainting and falling and
numbers that cannot be counted perish of
heart hunger heart thirst and heart
fatigue but he who will step aside from
the passionate press and will detain to
notice and to enter the byways which are
here presented his dusty feet shall
press the incomparable flowers of
blessedness his eyes be gladden with
their beauty and his mind refreshed with
their sweet perfume rested and sustained
he will escape the fever and is the
delirium of life strong and happy he
will not fall fainting in the dust nor
perish by the way but will successfully
accomplish his journey James Allen broad

devastating the whole town by fire
